item.title: Another point about Static Site Generators
item.description: Yes, static website site generators like http://gohugo.io are light on server resources and provide a great workflow. However there’s one limitation worth mentioning : editing on the go. Indeed when using a CMS like WordPress editing options abound for the wandering blogger. WordPress offers a dedicated iOS and Android app. Moreover other dedicated editors specialize in WordPress content creation. And last, you can default to using the web interface either through wordpress.

item.title: Code First, Granular Testing
item.description: Yes, TDD and BDD are great techniques, but is there a way to start testing when you’re a beginner developer and you seem to have a hard time getting into TDD or BDD? If at first TDD or BDD don’t seem to work for your brain you might want to try a different approach. There is nothing inherently wrong with these two testing paradigms. But I feel a different approach might work better for less-seasoned programmers like me.

item.title: YAML vs TOML
item.description: Hugo supports both YAML and TOML for configuration and content matter. You can even use JSON if you feel adventurous (less readable )

item.title: Welcome to Orbital Coding
item.description: Or should I say welcome again ? Switching to Hugo Orbital Coding now uses Hugo, a static site generator. Yes, WordPress is a great content management system, but it require a database and active server side code. Running code on the server alongside a database require more resources while increasing the attack surface.
